results.title: Le Fantome de la Liberte = The Phantom of Liberty
results.brief_description:
A series of casually linked episodes moving from Toledo in 1808 and Goya’s painting of ‘The executions of 3 May’ to contemporary Paris where various people try to grasp or shun, in Karl Marx’s phrase, ‘the phantom of liberty’. This is Bunuel’s very personal version of ‘La Ronde’. In eight sketches - each representing a different aspect of hypocrisy - he creates a succession of dazzling moments. The sketches use every type of comedy: there is an interval of French farce with slamming bedroom doors, two black jokes about cancer and mass murder and a piece of pure Ionesco. Each sketch has its point to make and its own authority figures to be lampooned. This is a delightful and hilarious Bunuelian masterpiece.

Credits: Producer: Serge Silberman ; director, Luis Bunuel ; writers, Luis Bunuel, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Edmond Richard.
Cast: Adriana Asti, Julien Bertheau, Michel Piccoli, Adolfo Celi, Milena Vukotic, Jean-Claude Brialy, Monica Vitti, Muni, Paul Frankeur, Michel Lonsdale, Pierre Maguelon, Framcois Maistre, Helene Perdriere, Claude Pieplu, Jean Rochefort, Bernard Verle

results.title: Le Doulos = the Finger Man
results.creator_credit: Georges de Beauregard and Jean-Pierre Melville
results.brief_description:
Maurice, just out of jail, seeks out revenge from a fence who had his wife killed. Maurice kills the fence and steels some jewellery which he hides. But the murder is not enough. Maurice prepares an other heist with Silien, whom the ‘milieu’ (the underworld) suspects to be a ‘doulos’ (an informer). ‘Le Doulos’ is one of Melville’s many homages to American Cinema. The sets for the offices of Commissaire Clain were modelled on those used by Ruben Mamoulian in ‘City Streets’. For the confrontation scene between Silien and Clain, Melville directed a 9 min. 39 sec. shot with a 360 degree pan.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, Jean-Pierre Melville ; writers, Jean-Pierre Melville, Elisabeth Rappeneau ; photography, Nicolas Hayer ; music, Paul Misraki ; art direction, Daniel Gueret, Pierre Charron ; assistant directior, Vol
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Serge Reggiani, Jean Desailly, Fabienne Dali, Michel Piccoli, Marcel Cuvelier, Jack Leonard, Aime de March, Monique Hennessy.

results.title: Le Dossier Francoise Muller = the Francoise Muller Case
results.brief_description:
Following an apparence on a TV show, economist Gerard Plantier is murdered in the underground garage of his appartment building. The only witnesses are his girlfriend, Francoise, and the night watchman. As the investigation progresses, it is revealed that Francoise had a rather shady past and that some of her former acquaintances may have something to do with Gerard’s death. To Judge Massot’s surprise, Francoise is doing her best to attract all the blame for the murder to herself.

Credits: Producer, Jean Gauthier ; director, Edouard Molinaro ; writer, Alphonse Boudard ; photography, Alain Levent ; music, Vladimir Cosma.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Michel Vitold, Jean-Claude Dauphin, Didier Haudepin, Bernard Pivot, Albert Simonin, Nathalie Delon, Jean-Pierre Darras, Andre Pousse, Saddy Rebbot, Katy Amaizo, Germaine Delbat, Andre Lacombe, Henry Rellys.

results.title: Le Divorce
results.creator_credit: Fox Searchlight Pictures, Merchant Ivory Productions, Radar Pictures, Michael Schiffer, Ismail Merchant and James Ivory
results.brief_description: A stellar ensemble cast in this romantic drama/comedy about a cultural clash between a French husband, his American wife (Naomi Watts) and her sister (Kate Hudson). From the creative team of Merchant Ivory comes this study of romantic relationships, wealth and culture. Based on the novel by Diane Johnson. Cast includes Glenn Close, Stephen Fry, Leslie Caron and Stockard Channing.

results.title: Le Dialogue des Carmelites = the Carmelites
results.creator_credit: Pierre Laurent, Philippe Agostini and R.L. Bruckberger
results.brief_description:
Two young carmelite novices take the veil almost on the eve of the French Revolution, and find themselves, their sister nuns and the convent itself caught up in the political events that follow.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Laurent ; director, Philippe Agostini, R. L. Bruckberger ; writers, Philippe Agostini, R. L. Bruckberger, Georges Bernanos ; photography, Andre Bac ; music, Jean Francaix.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Alida Valli, Pascale Audret, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Brasseur, Georges Wilson.

results.title: Le Diable Dans la Boite = the Devil in the Box
results.brief_description:
Satire about the expendability of personnel in a big contracting company challenged by the hunger strike of a young executive when he is fired with the vague reason of a re-structuring.

Credits: Producer, Mag Bodard ; director, Pierre Lary ; writers, Jean-Claude Carriere, Hugue Deboisieux, Pierre Lary ; photography, Sacha Vierny ; music, Jean-Claude Dequeant.
Cast: Jean Rochefort, Michel Lonsdale, Dominique Labourier, Anouk Ferjac, Micheline Presle.

results.title: Le Diable Boiteux = the Devil with a Limp
results.brief_description:
Sacha Guitry used Talleyrand’s nickname ‘the Devil with a limp’ as the starting point for a film on the first ‘Eurocrat’ and his life full of ups and downs, conspiracies and betrayals of every sort. From the Ancien Regime by whom Talleyrand was elevated to Bishop of Autun up to the reign of Louis-Philippe when he negotiated the peace with Britain, the path of this most famous political opportunist was played to the music of infidelity and the thirst for power. Talleyrand’s grand passions (money, women and power…) are filmed with outstanding cinematic finesse.

Credits: Producer, Jean Mugeli ; director, Sacha Guitry ; writer, Sacha Guitry ; photography, Nicolas Toporkoff ; music, Louis Beydts.
Cast: Pierre Bertin, Pauline Carton, Daniel Ceccaldi, Jean Debucourt, Emile Drain, Maurice Escande, Jeanne Fusier-Gir, Sacha Guitry, Robert Hossein, Lana Marconi, Jose Noguero, Jean Piat, Maurice Schutz, Renee Devillers.

results.title: Le Destin de Juliette = the Destiny of Juliette
results.brief_description:
Aline Isserman’s film chronicles twenty years of a woman’s life. Juliette, a simple country girl, is in love with Pierre, a sheperd but she is forced into a marriage with a boring railway worker in order to save her family from poverty and homelessness. The husband, Marcel, is transferred from post to post, and becomes an alcoholic, eventually dying, leaving Juliette free to rebuild her life.

Credits: Producer, Eric Lambert ; director, Aline Isserman ; writers, Michel Dufresne, Aline Isserman ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Bernard Lubat.
Cast: Laure Duthilleul, Richard Bohringer, Veronique Silver, Pierre Forget, Hippolyte Girardot.

results.title: Le Desordre et Apres (1960-1966) Part 11
results.brief_description:
Part 11 of 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By the mid-1960s the industry had reconciliated. The French filmgoing public, and most producers, had lost their sympathy for formal experiment and unbridled self-expression. But it would be an exaggeration to argue that French cinema was essentially unchanged, and that most of the films of the late 1960s resembled those of the previous decade. Much had, in fact, been irretrievably altered. The film community was no longer closed to new talent. New directors (for example, Constantin Costa-Gavras, in 1965) and other personnel entered the industry with much greater ease than during the ‘Tradition of Quality’, though most of them worked on unadventurous, if occasionaly stylish, commercial projects.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992 Our collection holds many of the titles referred to in this episode. Apart from a large selection of works by Truffaut, Melville, Chabrol and Godard of this particular decade, we also recommend the following: Rohmer’s ‘Le signe du Lion’ ; Astruc’s ‘La proie pour l’ombre’ and ‘La longue marche’ ; Franju’s ‘La tete contre les murs’ and ‘Judex’ ; Varda’s ‘Le bonheur’ and ‘Cleo de 5 a 7’ ; Michel Drach’s ‘On n’enterre pas le dimanche’ and ‘Amelie ou le temps d’aimer’ ; Resnais’s ‘L’annee derniere a Marienbad’ and ‘La guerre est finie’ ; Colpi’s ‘Une aussi longue absence’ ; Deville’s ‘Ce soir ou jamais’ and ‘Adorable menteuse’ ; Robert Enrico’s ‘Au coeur de la vie’ ; Alain Robbe-Grillet’s ‘L’immortelle’, ‘L’homme qui ment’ and ‘Glissement progressifs du plaisir’ ; Henri Verneuil’s ‘Melodie en sous-sol’.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Cast: Includes interviews with: Louis Malle, Pierre Granier-Deferre, Pierre Kast, Claude Chabrol, Alain Robbe-Grillet, Eric Rohmer.

results.title: Le Desordre a Vingt Ans = Disorder Is Twenty Years Old
results.brief_description:
In this documentary, Jacques Baratier compares life in the St Germain des Pres area of Paris in the the post WWII years and 20 years later in the Sixties (pre May 68). Rare documents and seldom seen footage of personalities, “overexposed films shot in obscure places” such as ‘Le Tabou’ recreate the ambiance of the great existentialist era. The interviewees recall the social changes that led to the movement. They include: Boris Vian, Alain Vian, Roger Blin, Juliette Greco, Raymond Queneau, Jean Cau, Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Paul Sartre, Sophie Desmarets, Jean Cocteau, Roger Pierre, Arthur Adamov, Cesar, Anne-Marie Cazalis, Michel de Re, Roger Vadim, Annabel, Gabriel Pomerand, Sydney Bechet, Claude Luter etc… This film is followed by ‘Voila l’ordre’.

Credits: Director, Jacques Baratier.
